Report
Prospective Resident
Visited 2016 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/04/2017
the forest apartments has had 4 or 5 management companies over the past 3-4 years. They are condescending, inconsiderate and rude individuals in the office. The laundry area is gross and out of service much of the time. The fitness area is dirty and half if the equipment is faulty. The buildings are jack leg rigged up then painted over. The renovations and repairs look like they were done by amateurs. The pool is decent, but the drain to rise off is stopped up and you have to stand in dirty stagnant water with mosquito larvae floating in it. The worst part of the place is the nasty attitudes of the staff. Good luck getting someone on the phone that has any answers to your questions. They will put you on hold to ask someone else or transfer the call to someone who would rather not be talking to you in the first place.

Resident
2013 - 2016 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/26/2016
I have lived at the Forest now for three years. If you had me write this review when I first moved in it would have been less-than-stellar (see negative reviews below). Now on our 5th management company in three years, I can say that they FINALLY got it right! The staff at the Forest have totally changed the place around. Brand new Tennis Courts, brand new grills, an updated pool area where people actually hang out, new gym equipment...all for the best deal in Durham and in a great, quiet location. Management has been responsive to my concerns that have come up. And, though I LOVED the old maintenance folks, the new maintenance team is professional and courteous and does a great job. I've lived in Durham for 8 years now, 3 at the Forest. Would highly recommend.

Report
Resident
2011 - 2016 Not Recommended Reviewed 05/02/2016
I've lived here 5 years. In that 5 years, there have been 5 property management companies and I'm not sure how many owners. Rent has gone from $550 to $639 for a studio apartment with 1980's fixtures. When my refrigerator died, they did not give me a new refrigerator -- I was given another 80's vintage refrigerator with rust on it. They repainted the complex about a year ago. It took only a couple of days and it shows -- the door is sloppily painted (door is painted red and it's all over the door jamb, which is not red apart from the red door paint splashed on it). They also painted the stairs a light color which started showing dirt immediately -- plus started chipping almost as quickly. Basically, the management companies to date have gone for cheap rather than good. There was a car stolen from the complex not long ago, but the theft rate is lower than it was a few years ago when there was a rash of burglaries. If you rent here, definitely go for a 2nd floor apartment to decrease the chance of burglary. To be honest, I don't think the apartments are worth the rent they're charging now, so I'm moving. It is, however, 2 miles from Duke West Campus and on the city bus line, so it is convenient if you study or work on campus.

Report
Resident
2014 - 2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 02/09/2016
I would not recommend this complex - look elsewhere if you have other options. Good things: the location is OK, the apartments themselves are not bad, the access to Duke Forest is nice, and the price was reasonable. Bad things: management is terrible and is constantly changing. While the office staff are friendly, they do not respond to any requests on your first try. Be used to asking several times for any maintenance requests or any issues with lease or payment. Also beware - while touring the facilities, they showed me a unit with a balcony and claimed my unit would also have a balcony. After signing the lease, I found out that my actual unit was very different from the one I was shown. If you get a unit without laundry hookups, be aware that the on-site laundry facilities are not cleaned very much and the washers and dryers themselves are constantly breaking down. I lost money many times in those machines. Finally, don't expect to get your security deposit back. This on its own is not unexpected, as some cleaning charges are reasonable, but don't expect any updates/information on your deposit's status. They will disregard all attempts to contact them until you call them in person or send several emails. On the whole, dealing with management (or the several management teams that may take over during your stay there, as it always seems to be changing) is pretty frustrating.

Resident
2014 - 2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/21/2015
Whatever you give them for a deposit, don't expect to see it again. I lived there on a one year lease. During that time, at least three of the apartments in the complex were broken in to. One time I was woken up in the night with some guy I've never seen before banging on the door trying to get me to let him in. The water pipes are basically not insulated, so they randomly freeze and cut off the water in the winter. When I moved out, I left the apartment spotless with no balance on my account, yet I've called the office five times over the past three months and the deposit has not been returned. The office staff seems nice enough, but every time I would stop by or call, it's a new person working there.

Report
Resident
2015 Recommended Property Reviewed 09/12/2015
First things first; The Forest IS a decent place to live. It's in a great location, generally quiet and pretty affordable. The pool area is nice. I think, like many properties, the staff can only do so much given limitations placed on them by the property management company. This said, there are some issues: 1.) There are small things they could easily take care of - and don't; broken outdoor lighting, tiles missing from the laundry room, dirty bathrooms by the pool, new signage which looked great -- that now seems to not be working. They give each resident a security code for the mail and laundry room, and then never bother to use the lock. And the laundry room is generally a mess, especially after the weekend. Not sure how they give tours and let people see this! 2.) I think your satisfaction depends on your neighbors -- there are certain buildings I would NOT want to live in, due to noise or the potential for being broken into; some units, especially first floor in the outer buildings, are very isolated and dark. They need to install better lighting. 3.) There are hundreds of apartments in about 18-20 buildings, and 3-4 maintenance staff to handle them all; they are overworked, and, in some cases, incompetent. Again, I think they are also pressured to take shortcuts to save money, Needless to say, maintenance is not "top notch" - the staff are friendly enough, but, again, I think overworked and somewhat under-skilled. 4.) Their staff turnover is insane - which I see as not a good sign; in my first few months here all the office staff except the manager changed several times, and then she was gone too (we recently got a new manager who seems OK so far). Property management needs to know this kind of turnover reflects poorly on the community and their management. Overall, this is a fine place if you pick the right unit, pester management when needed, and don't see it as a long-term home.

Report
Resident
2015 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/09/2015
The Forest Apartments is a great place to live in Durham. My experience with this apartment complex has been positive since Day 1. I moved here from the NY/NJ area for a job; therefore, I know firsthand what a nightmare apartment hunting can be. Kathy Woodard, the Manager at The Forest Apartments, personally reached out to me via e-mail and made my apartment hunt pleasant and fun from Day 1. Her first e-mail to me said: "I have a gorgeous studio that's ready for move in TODAY! It is darling. Our studio's are not just a square box as most are. They are... 'suave'. Come see me today and I will show you." To which I responded: "Haha this sounds too good to be true, but I'll keep an open mind :-) Will do my best to come by today." To which she responded: "Underpromise, over deliver! See you later today!" The Forest has delivered. I have lived here since March of this year (so about 3 months total), and am really enjoying it. I visited about 18 other apartment complexes in the area before deciding on The Forest, and I could not be happier. I have everything I need and for a price I can afford. I saw a few cheaper places a bit closer to downtown Durham, but they did not have all the amenities that the Forest has (a dishwasher, a pool, a gym, a laundry room, a community, grass, picnic tables, and tennis courts). I also just helped a friend apartment hunt last week and went to a few different luxury apartment complexes in Durham, and at the end of the day, I felt very grateful for my cozy studio- as I said I have everything I need (I don't need valet trash service, a car wash on site, and $200 more a month in rent :-) ) This place is a hidden gem. Thank you to Kathy and The Forest Apartment staff for welcoming me with open arms since Day 1. I'm happy and blessed to call this place home.

Report
Resident
2015 Recommended Property Reviewed 04/19/2015
We only recently moved in and been staying here for a month, but so far our experience has been positive. The apartment is in good condition, renovated, stove/dishwasher are brand new, nice shades (not the cheapest and ugly looking ones), clean, good laminate floors. Maybe not everything is perfect-perfect, but it seems to be worth the money I'm paying. Washer/dryer is optional for extra $35 a month, but I just purchased my own second-hand washer for only $30+20 delivery (they have GOOD thrift stores in Durham) and it make much more economic sense to me - no need to constantly b**ch about laundry facility, as other reviewers do. Even though we used it once and was fully satisfied. The location is amazing, very close to Duke Forest, but at the same time it only take 5-10 mins driving to get pretty much anywhere in Durham, and it's very close to highways. Also the place is pet-friendly. Our manager was Kathy Woodard - very friendly and nice, walk us through the whole signing process nice and easy, explaining everything clearly, answering all questions. Basically it was my first experience with apartment complex, and she did good to make it a pleasant one. All other staff we met so far was very friendly too, they responded to our maintenance requests quickly and did good job. They still didn't come back with a few things, though non-urgent ones. Neighbors are a bit noisy sometimes, but only during daytime and never late at night. Also, we can be noisy ourselves, so can't complain. Cellphone reception is not very good inside, at least for AT&T. Verizon works fine to me. The territory is really well-lit at night time (which is especially good since it is basically in the middle of the forest) and here i have zero complaints. A lot of parking spots. We didn't regret our decision to choose the place, and fantastic location beats everything. I'm only rating it 4 stars, because we didn't stay long enough to maybe uncover some potential drawbacks, experience more maintenance to really give it a fair mark and even explore thoroughly gym/swimming pool, etc. I will try to get back here with a follow-up in - say - 6 months and report my opinion after staying here for a while. PS. Apart from clearly trolling/vandalizing 1-star reviews about the place being "WORST ON EARTH" (duh, really?) or management being horrible (clearly not true), I saw some thorough and detailed bad reviews from people who claim to be living here for 3-4-5 years. One thing I don't understand about it is - if the place is so bad, why aren't you moving out? So I'm looking at those reports with some criticism. It must be not so bad if people are still staying here or tolerate it for years.
We only recently moved in and been staying here for a month, but so far our experience has been positive. The apartment is in good condition, renovated, stove/dishwasher are brand new, nice shades (not the cheapest and ugly looking ones), clean, good laminate floors. Maybe not everything is perfect-perfect, but it seems to be worth the money I'm paying. Washer/dryer is optional for extra $35 a month, but I just purchased my own second-hand washer for only $30+20 delivery (they have GOOD thrift stores in Durham) and it make much more economic sense to me - no need to constantly b**ch about laundry facility, as other reviewers do. Even though we used it once and was fully satisfied. The location is amazing, very close to Duke Forest, but at the same time it only take 5-10 mins driving to get pretty much anywhere in Durham, and it's very close to highways. 2015 Recommended Property Reviewed 04/13/2015
I moved to Durham April 1st and had rented a place sight-unseen (though I saw many pictures and spoke with the potential landlord and even verified her references) that ended up not working out. Luckily I remembered the Forest! I visited and was immediately impressed with the location (very woodsy/Duke Forest trails), the renovations and the helpfulness of the staff. The Property Manager, Kathy, went above and beyond to get me into a renovated 1-BR quickly and, though it's only been about 2 weeks, I have been very happy; in general it's quiet, convenient to Duke and areas like 9th Street (by car), and the pool and laundry areas are nice amenities and well-kept, and I can't wait to use the tennis courts. So far maintenance has been responsive, too. My only complaint would be that, if you pay your rent using a credit or debit card, they charge you a fairly high fee (and you cannot pay in cash) -- which seems a little crazy to me (I pay everything online these days). It COSTS me $25 to pay my rent? Really? Otherwise I'm happy there so far!

Resident
2011 - 2015 Not Recommended Reviewed 02/27/2015
I want to say this, and I hope all prospective tenants are reading this review. The Forest Apartments is a nice community and presents itself in such a fashion, the community, is very friendly group of people, the staff while, friendly, is highly unprofessional and uncaring of their loyal tenants. The forest were undertaken by a new group of people, and things have progressively gotten worse for the betterment of the tenants ( They were somewhat better in how they handled certain situations in the past). During their transition, to the community they wasted a lot of money by trying to "spruce up" everything while leaving out a lot of unaddressed and important stuff. The staff is uncaring of you or your concerns, unwilling to work with you if can't manage to pay your rent on time, and they are super strict on 'policing' every effort to remove any debris or trash from your porch, Even if it was temporarily put there for disposal. I've been living here for 4 years and I'm still treated like a new tenant. if you miss just 1 single day on your rent, guess how much they charge you? 30 dollars extra, just for being 1 DAY late, and 30+ dollars for each subsequent day. Maintenance is horrible, as they can take days and even weeks until your work order is fulfilled. When it snows, the office is closed, and the community pavement is completely covered with snow. Some cars can't even get out of the drive way, all the while I'm looking at the maintenance guys from the apartment complex across the street clear the way for their tenants. The community is becoming unsafe as well. there have been a number of robberies in the community, and all the Forest does is stick a note to your door alerting you. (they seem to be a bunch of passive aggressive people who like to sneak up to your door hoping you don't hear them only to stick a note on it complaining or notifying you about something) Only when the situation gets worse do they dispatch "security guards" to patrol the area. They do not patrol the area on an hourly basis, more like once or twice a week, but now that the holidays are gone, they've stopped caring about peoples security because those guards are no where to be found. The worst part about the break ins is that they occur DURING BROAD DAYLIGHT. The Forest seem unwilling to hire additional guards to REGULARLY PATROL the area. These guys simply don't care. The laundry room is nice too, I guess.. when the machines work. And on more than one occasion their machines have taken my money due to non working machines with NO NOTICE on them. Told the staff about it, said they would deduct it from my rent, but didn't even ask where I stayed or who I was. The ONLY good thing about this place is that its close to duke. But best believe when our contract expires we're getting the heck up outta here! So in conclusion, staff is unprofessional, maintenance sucks and is unprofessional/ do half assed jobs, community feels unsafe, staff has no concept of tenant loyalty. I'm sure there are many many other things I could go on about but i feel i've made my point very clear which is.. take your money somewhere else.

Resident
2014 Not Recommended Reviewed 10/16/2014
The Forest has only one thing going for it: the location. Other than that, our experience was utterly terrible. My wife and I rented an apartment for 3 months while we looked for a home to purchase. During our time, we found: 1) The place is not well kept. Bugs were everywhere in the apartment, the dumpsters were hardly maintained, the workout facility was dirty and barely had any working machines, and the laundry facility (when operable) was disgusting. 2) The staff seems very nice, but they are crooks. Do not believe what they tell you on the phone. At the last minute, they added a $375 pet fee that they said we wouldn't have to pay. Then they add a $15 "pet rent." So, we paid $420 over 3 months to have our dogs. THEN, they charged $50 for a carpet cleaning on the tail end. 3) Maintenance was awful. One night our tub faucet would not turn off (it constantly leaked anyways). We called the "emergency maintenance line"--what a joke. The next morning, I called first thing. They said they'd have someone out in the next 30 minutes. I waited 2 hours, then called again. Same thing; it'd just be a few minutes. Finally, by 9 pm (24 hours after I filed the complaint) they sent someone out. 4) The staff (though nice) is incompetent. When my security deposit return was much less than expected (surprise surprise) I called 3 times to talk to the manager. Each time they said my call would be returned within 30 minutes. Finally, two weeks later, I had to email to get a reply. I would not recommend this apartment complex to anyone. It's incredibly expensive for what you get. They steal every penny from you, and you don't get much in return. Stay away.

Resident
2014 Not Recommended Reviewed 04/20/2014
I've lived in the Forest Apartments for about two years now, and to say the least I will be looking forward to ending my lease. I chose to live at the Forest because the rates were reasonable and the drive wasn't too far from Duke. Now mind you, I'm not picky about my living environment (I've lived in the most dingy hostels across the world, so anything even remotely basic is appreciated). However, they recently increased their rates to be unproportionately high with the quality of living. Seriously, for the same rate, I can get an actual luxury apartment closer to Duke that has twice the space and no problems with roaches. But most infuriating of all is the service of the management office. For nearly all requests both by phone and in person, I was treated with the utmost level of disrespect, and have been accused of things being my fault. For instance, I had a leaky faucet one weekend and was told that this was not an emergency, so someone would be by during the week. I finally got service on Wednesday after numerous calls with the same "non-emergency" response. I know the Forest isn't exactly a "green" apartment, but my water bill doubled that month. I know my house isn't on fire, but I'm really curious as to what else on the grounds is more critical than this. If you like being disrespected by management, paying exorbitant prices, and dealing with outdated facilities, by all means live here. But if you're not, then please look for somewhere else. This place has no hope of improving.

If at any time a resident has an issue with their apartment we encourage them to please contact the office so that we may address their concerns and resolve them as quickly as possible. These changes are to only be addressed by a professional ? your maintenance team. If you are still a resident here please contact the office and let us know what issues you are having in your apartment so that we may put in a work order and at least make the rest of your time with us a more pleasurable.

Report
Resident
2011 - 2013 Recommended Property Reviewed 10/03/2013
Reading other reviewers posts I'm pretty surprised at the negative comments. I've had an overall good experience here. Perhaps the other reviewers are expecting too much. The apartments are on the cheaper side and are one of the few truly pet friendly complexes near Duke (which was a big deal for me). They are not super frilly places (if you need that go spend the bajillion dollars to live at Station 9 with the Fuqua kids). If you're like me and are a young hardworking professional or someone not making a ton of cash this is a great place to live. Maintenance is super friendly and makes sure the essentials are taken care of, pest management comes on a regular basis, and the office staff is amazing. Angel, Helen, and Stasia all took wonderful care of me throughout my stay and made me feel like a friend and not just another tenant. Also, since the new management has come in (I signed my lease under the old one) they have been doing renovations to the apartments one by one. I'd echo another reviewer and say to look at the ACTUAL apartment you are renting because they do vary a lot. I was happy here. The neighbors were a wonderful mix of students, professionals, families, and travelers and it was always very quiet. I am a young, single woman and never had any of the issues with break-ins that others have, though I did hear about them. Use common sense: lock your car doors, remove valuables from sight, keep your blinds shut if you're not home, etc. and you'll be fine. It's no worse than anywhere else in that area of Durham. If you don't need excessive accomodations, want a decent place for a decent price, and value renting from genuinely kind people then this is a good pick.

Report
Resident
2012 - 2013 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/13/2013
Ehhhhh. This place was ok. You get what you pay for. It was close to Duke and cheap, but any savings I might have gotten were canceled out by my apartment getting robbed and having to deal with losing a bunch of electronics, etc. The locks were super flimsy (when a guy came to fix my door after it had been kicked in, he told me none of the apartments had bolts that were attached to studs, so all that was standing between the outside and inside of an apartment was about half an inch of weak plaster), I rarely saw any security presence, and I never felt safe at night or with my blinds up. This might be less of an issue if you're on the second floor. When my apartment was broken into, no one showed up to fix anything until the afternoon of the next day, so I had to sit at home in an insecure apartment (most of one night and part of the next day!) with my remaining belongings until someone showed up. When things were fixed, they were generally fine, but not great. For example, when my door was kicked in, there was all this bare, cracked plaster around it, and a layer of missing plaster, even after the lock was fixed. I put in a maintenance request, and someone eventually showed up and slapped a bunch of paint over the bare plaster. Of course, because a bunch of plaster came off when the door was kicked in, the whole area around the door was uneven and at a different layer than the rest of the wall. The maintenance man was extremely friendly, though. Bright spot! Fixtures are cheap and minimally maintained. My tub never drained properly, which meant I had to either soak up the remaining water with a towel or let it sit and grow mold. There were occasional cockroaches, but I expect that in the south and I don't think this place was infested. The door frame and building exterior had some rot. The best thing about the complex is its proximity to Duke Forest and running trails. Laundry facilities were adequate, and it was nice that they were onsite, but the building was grimy and sometimes the machines smelled pretty strongly of mold. There was a door that was supposed to be locked, but I don't think it was ever locked. I had a door code, but I never had to use it. I had no trouble getting my security deposit back, but if I could go back and sign another lease, I'd pay more for a safer, nicer place. I also hear they're raising rents to be more in line with other apartments in the area, so I'd go with those other apartments if I were you.

But I have enough chances to encounter many different kinds of bugs. The bright side is that I am pretty confident that I can be an expert in bugs. Not only cockroaches, spiders, ants and many other that I can't name. There is a hole around the circle for over one year and still there when I came back to visit a friend. The door to the mail room is always broken. Good thing is I don't have to memorize the code. The apartment itself is OK. Depending on which one you choose. Believe me , don't live on the first floor. A little exercise with the stairs won't make you regret. I had mold problems when I lived on the first floor.Double check when you look at the apartments since it is easier to climb the Himalayas than to transfer apartments once you signed the lease. They will swear to you they don't have any but still advertise on the website and show potential renters around. The neighbors are great. That may be the other reason that I lived there for two years. They are mostly duke students. Quiet and friendly. But not those from the nightly rent apts. They are usually loud since they don't really care and you can't complain since they may not be there the next day and you are not sure what's their background.

Resident
2012 Not Recommended Reviewed 09/07/2012
I had stayed in the Forest Apartments twice before. Once, for two weeks when our son started Duke Medical School, and once, six months later, when I went down for a visit. It is important to note that my son, not me, rented an apartment for a year, while I was there for short periods - either three days or two weeks. But for all times sakes I went back for a short-term stay (three days) last week and was profoundly disappointed. From my lost reservation to no towels, toilet paper, a used bed and much more, it was an terrible reception, indeed. While Stacia did spend two hours after our arrival trying to make things right - and she came a long way in doing so - I'd never go back. The Forest Apartments may well be in the business of renting apartments month-by-month, but they are not - at least any longer - in the business of accommodating a short-term stay. Even their apologies rang hollow after a while.

Resident
2009 - 2012 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/22/2012
I had a pretty great experience at the Forest. I lived in my apartment for 3 years and had a solidly pleasant experience. I have read the other reviews and can confirm that there were a number of break-ins over the last year. I was fortunate to not experience this personally, my apartment and my car were unmolested for my entire residence here. Maintenance, though it's changed over the years a number of times, was always courteous and prompt. In all honesty, I didn't have many problems with my apartment! My main suggestion for potential renters is this: SEE the apartment you're interested in leasing before you sign anything! The appliances and fixtures vary apartment to apartment and you'll want to know if the previous tenant was a smoker (which mine was and the complex did not make much effort at cleaning out the apartment after him/her.) Other than wishing I'd viewed the apartment first, I have no real complaints. Always had hot water, always had good water pressure, the complex was quiet and my neighbors were nice, the front office staff is polite and usually helpful, the grounds were maintained neatly, always able to find parking, it was near Duke Campus, and honestly, the price was right at the time (not sure what the apartments are going for now, but I paid at least a hundred to two hundred less than some of my classmates.) Just keep in mind, you get what you pay for.

Report
Resident
2006 - 2012 Not Recommended Reviewed 04/14/2012
Where do I start? I guess with the fact that I moved into this apartment in September 2006, after leaving an apartment with black mold so thick my walls were furry. Little did I know that this place would ultimately have a more insidious problem, mold that could not be seen until it was too late. Everyone who moved in back then was subjected to not only a credit check but a background check as well. That meant the people who were here were mostly Duke grad students and hard working older people. I loved my apartment, it was small but cozy and was very very quiet. I had neighbors who were pleasant and friendly. Even the choir director who lived next door and had practice every Thursday evening could not be heard. I'm not sure how much they do now but it appears not nearly enough. I had a few minor problems over the first couple of months. Some bugs that I'm told are normal in this area and a gap around the front door that really can't be fixed but a good rug prevents air from coming in. My bathroom sink had nothing more than a trickle of hot water. Cold was great but no hot. I reported the situation and several weeks later the faucet was replaced. Didn't make a difference. So I mentioned it to the head of maintenance and he came down to check for himself. He found a piece of plastic about six inches long in the hose that connected to the faucet. The person who replaced the faucet didn't notice it. When what Southerners refer to as "winter" came, it got cold in the apartment so naturally I turned on the furnace. It got COLDER in the apartment. I contacted management and they had maintenance come down to change the air filter in the furnace. Three filters later, I found if I turned the furnace to emergency heat I could actually get the temperature up to 65 which for a Yankee like me is comfortable. Finally, I just pulled on more clothes and up until last winter tried each year to get some heat in my apartment. Even now if I set the furnace to "normal" heating the fan will run all day, at my expense, and the temperature will not get above 60. During that same winter I noticed my shower had very little hot water. My shower would start off nice but the water would turn cold after only two minutes. Yes I actually timed it. I reported the situation and the new maintenance guys came down and turned up the thermostat on the water heater. Made no difference except now the thermostat began to wear out. After several repeated attempts to "fix" the problem by changing the settings on the water heater, I gave up. I learned to take a very quick shower and to keep my hair short so I could actually rinse the soap out before I became a popsicle. In all fairness this was fixed by Jessica, one of the best managers this place has ever had and let go. She was the one who got me a water saver shower head that actually worked. 2008 started off well until April. At that point there was a large stain in the ceiling in the bathroom. Called maintenance and they checked the upstairs apartment and found nothing wrong so they assumed they had a one off leak. They painted the ceiling and things seemed good until early May when I started having severe and regular asthma attacks. Not long after these started, I noticed a "bubble" in the plaster in the ceiling where the guys had painted. On May 19th I was doing my business and the ceiling literally fell on my head. Called maintenance and they again checked upstairs but found nothing. They pulled down the rest of the plaster and I was able to see that the insulation, what there was of it, was absolutely BLACK and was dripping water. The new head of maintenance informed me that insulation was supposed to be black. I'm no genius but I spent my college years doing home renovations to earn some money and I KNOW that black insulation is not normal. I also mentioned that the wall board behind the toilet was "soft". Maintenance told me that management decided to re-plaster and repaint and that was all they were going to do until I got angry and demanded they fix the problem correctly. At that point I informed management, if they didn't put me in another apartment until the ceiling was properly fixed, I was going to a hotel and staying there at their expense. I was moved to one of the corporate apartments on May 22nd and finally returned to the apartment on June 6th. The maintenance guy informed me that they had discovered the skylight above my upstairs neighbor was leaking and that is where the water was coming from. Strangely enough, she didn't notice any problems so how was the water from her ceiling getting to my ceiling?? By the way, the wall was not repaired. In 2009, I was walking to my car early in the morning and stepped on a piece of concrete that had been heaved up by tree roots. I ended up with a broken foot. The difference in the pieces of sidewalk was close to two inches. The solution was not to fix the broken light that kept this discrepancy in the dark, but to paint a white line at the crack so you could see where it was. There is a pole light between my building and the next one that has been on less that a week out of the last 6 years despite repeated notification. This makes the area, and the sidewalk between the two building absolutely pitch black. With the trees it's a great place to have someone hide. Summer of 2009, I went on vacation for a week. I came home to find my door unlocked, the front light on and the faucet in the bathroom running wide open. According to management, no one had been in the apartment so I must have left it open and the water running when I left. $125.00 for a water bill that month and I must have "forgotten" to turn it off? Two weeks later I come home to the door unlocked again. At this point I had maintenance change the lock. The back door to my "sun room" has 3 locks on it but the front door has only one? October 2010 was when things really started going bad. I went out one morning to find not only my car but my neighbor's car had been broken into. Management's response was that we tenants should be more watchful. I could only guess that, since the break-ins occurred between midnight and five am, they meant that one of us should sit up nights watching the cars. This was under the only street light in the area and across the street from out "courtesy" officer, a police officer with a K9 unit. Between October and January there were at least another dozen car break-ins. NO alert was given by management. I guess we were supposed to find out on our own. January 2011, I was doing my laundry early in the morning, the only time when washers and dryers were available thanks to people who leave their clothes in the laundry for hours and even days. I came out to my car, again parked under a street light, to find someone in the front seat cutting my radio out of the dash. I know I'm considered an idiot but I yelled at the man to get out of my car. I ended up being pushed down before I could hit the panic button. Fortunately, once the alarm went off, the man took off, as did the second man that I hadn't seen in the back of the car. They got my radio but left behind a pristine finger print and a screwdriver. I know I was very lucky that the screwdriver and the knife they used to get the radio weren't used on me. The next day there was a notice on the door of the laundry room basically saying it was the tenant's responsibility to take precautions against theft and attacks. I was picking up a package at the office and as I was walking out a young man was walking in wearing the same outfit as the second man from the night before. He saw me, then very quickly looked away to prevent me from clearly seeing his face. Two days later I saw the same young man with the man who had pushed me down at the bus stop. Again, they turned away quickly when they saw my car. I called the police but by the time they got here, the two men were long gone. When I mentioned the young man to the manager, I was told they knew exactly who I was talking about but they wouldn't give me any information because he was "a quiet tenant who always paid his rent on time". Later that week I saw this man walking through the parking lot with his dog. Again I'm not an expert but I know a pit bull when I see one. I informed management of this and was told he didn't have a dog and that pit bulls weren't allowed in the complex. When I pressed the issue I was promised that the "courtesy" officer would keep an eye on him. In June of last year my air conditioner stopped putting out cold air. Maintenance was called again and again the unit was not repaired. I can handle cold but the heat in this area is way to much for a Northerner like me. They came on Friday to replace the A/C unit. I came home to find a man I did not know in my apartment without the required 24 hour notice. He is lucky, as am I that my dog did not bite him. He discovered after disconnecting the old unit that the unit they had him installing was not the correct kind. So he went to see if he could get the right part and didn't come back. I found out from the office that this man was only here temporarily, that day was his last day and they would have to wait until Monday when the new maintenance man arrived to fix the unit. Fortunately the temperature wasn't that hot that particular weekend. I came home Monday to discover the unit was still not fixed. A call to the office resulted in my being told that the new maintenance man wouldn't come into the apartment because the dog was running loose. My dog was locked in the bedroom which is next to the entrance. The man thought he was loose because he was barking at the only window which is right by the door. They offered to have the guy come down right away. An hour later I called again to be told he was there, but that it looked like it was going to rain so he left. No knock, no call and still no air. The unit was finally fixed a week after it was reported. From January of last year until April of this year, the break-ins escalated from cars to apartments. I spoke with one officer who was parked in front of my building and was told there had been "another" break-in. When I questioned the "another" he told me there had been 8 break-ins in the previous three months. I was working with Durham police re my mugging and was told that the officer in charge was actively participating in an operation where undercover police officers were being put into the complex to see if they could stop the break-ins and, while they knew who was doing it, they couldn't get enough proof to put a stop to it. One woman who is physically handicapped actually had her door kicked in while she was there. Fortunately some people heard her screaming and chased the thief off. No alert was given by management. OH, they painted the buildings last year. Painted my back door shut so I can't get it open. Again, in all fairness, I don't use that door much and, if I had to get out, I definitely WOULD get out. At least I'm secure in the knowledge that door won't be broken in without my knowing it. They supposedly power washed all of the buildings before painting them. Interestingly enough, there are cocoons and hornets nests that are now a part of the building having been covered with paint. After the painting, the overhead light on the stairwell going to the second floor burned out every 4 to 6 weeks. That makes the front entry of all of the apartments in this building pitch black. It usually took at least three e-mails or calls to the office to get this situation taken care of. In the meantime, those of us leaving before dawn or getting home after dark, were forced to feel our way to the door or up the stairs unless someone left their front door light on. Late last month, I was finally called to do a photo lineup to see if I could identify my mugger, like I'd be able to do so after 14 months. I came close but chose the wrong guy. I was told then that, while the police knew who he was, the man was not in custody and they "hoped he had moved on". I was also told that the officer had just returned from the complex after investigating 3 break-ins that had occurred in broad daylight that very day. WHY, might anyone ask, have I stayed in this apartment with all of the crap that has been going down. Simply put, it's close to my work and the rent is reasonable. Also, every time my lease came up for renewal, we had a new management company that had just taken over or was taking over, and I hoped against hope they would actually make things better. And finally, the bad things seem to happen when I'm in the middle of a lease. I don't have the money to buy out the remaining months or to take them to court as my neighbor did (and she DID win) to get out early. I tell myself, at this point, a couple of months of peanut butter for breakfast, lunch and dinner, would have been worth it. Twice in the past 8 months, the management company has changed. The result was that we lost the best of the groups to date and have been inconvenienced because those of us who pay online were not informed until just days, hours in one case, before the rent is due. You can't just drop your rent in a box at the office if you pay by check, you have to give it to a human. For those of us who work odd hours this means going out of our way to get to the office during the hours of operation. After all that has happened in the past year, I've become afraid to walk out the door in the dark. Especially after finding out that the guy who mugged me is NOT in custody. One of my former neighbors has told me that she saw two men who resembled the two across the street from my apartment hiding behind the dumpsters. She may have been wrong, but how can I be sure? I had decided not to renew my lease this time but once again a new manager came in and I thought I would give her a chance. BUT, once again, things have happened and I was fortunate that I could change my mind before the lease was up. The rent was screwed up again and we found out when the old company sent an e-mail cancelling the payment. They COULD have taken the payment and made us fight to get it back but fortunately they were honorable this time. In addition to this I received a notice on my door on March 7th that my lease had expired the day before and that I needed to come to the office to discuss this matter. I called because my lease is supposed to run until June 30th, and was told it was a "word processor" error and they were just trying to let me know that the lease was coming to an end. I don't know about you, but if I was sending out a notice like that, I would CHECK it before it was delivered. I did however find out that my lease did NOT run to June 30th but was actually up on June 28th. Had I not called I would have not known of the difference and my vacate notice would not have been given in time to allow for a 60 day notice. On Monday of this week, I received a reminder that I needed to let the office know if I was going to renew my lease. Yesterday I sent my notice to vacate in June. I sent the notice certified mail, return receipt requested. Today received a phone call telling me that they had received my notice but that it wasn't valid unless I came into the office and signed an "Official" notice. NONE of this was mentioned in the reminder because they "don't expect people to want to leave". When I suggested they might THINK about putting that in the notice, I was told I didn't have to send the vacate notice certified, it says so in the lease that I didn't get. I went to the office, read and signed the paperwork, and was THEN given a one page, two column list of items that needed to be taken care of when I moved or I would be fined. These items were supposedly listed in my lease - oh, by the way, did I mention that I too did not get a copy of the lease? Regardless I KNOW nothing was in the lease saying that I had to have the carpet "professionally cleaned" and that I must provide them with a receipt for said cleaning or I will be fined even though I own and use my own steam cleaner. The tile (linoleum at best) floors are to be cleaned AND waxed. OH, but the good news is I can hire them to do it for me for only $105.00 When I tried to get the signed paperwork back, I was told I had already signed it so too bad, so sad. I asked about the fact that they were doing a "pre move-out" walk thru in the "next few days" and I hoped they still had the copies of the pictures I took of the tile peeling back from the wall and the blinds on the back door that were broken when I moved in in 2006. Of course, they don't so I'm sure they will be trying to fine me for that too. To say the least I had planned to clean the apartment before I left. I have lived in many apartments in my life and have never had so much as one complaint about the way I had left them. At this point I'm not going to waste my time. I'll pay the $105.00 and consider it money well spent to be rid of these people. ********************* UPDATE **************************** Today I FINALLY received a copy of my lease. In the document was a paragraph, helpfully highlighted by the agent, that reads "38. Cleaning. You must thoroughly clean the apartment, including the doors, windows, furniture, bathrooms, kitchen appliances, patios, balconies, carports and storage rooms. You mus follow move-out cleaning instructions IF THEY HAVE BEEN PROVIDED. If you don't clean adequately, you'll be liable for reasonable cleaning charges." They seem to think this allows them to provide random cleaning instructions at any time and change them as they see fit...they might want to think again! 1) The cleaning instructions were provided ONLY after I signed the notice to vacate. 2) There is NO mention in the lease of PROFESSIONAL cleaning of the carpets. My attorney has read the lease and has given me the following advice. There is no document in existence that has my signature acknowledging that I would have the apartment professionally cleaned nor was I notified AT THE TIME THE LEASE WAS SIGNED that it would be necessary for me to do so. The notice of professional cleaning is not with the "four corners of the contract" allowing this management to randomly make changes without my knowledge or my approval. This is not only highly unethical but could be just cause for legal action. They've already lost one lawsuit. I'm willing now to go for two. Adding I TRULY feel sorry for the person who moved into this apartment next. I'm sure that the best they can hope for is painting over the mold and if they are really lucky new carpet that will hide the stains on the under-layment for a few months at best. One more note: My copy of the lease, that I finally received, shows an end date of June 30th, 2012, not the 28th as I've been repeatedly told. Make sure you read the lease carefully and GET A COPY!!

Management's response was that we tenants should be more watchful. I could only guess that, since the break-ins occurred between midnight and five am, they meant that one of us should sit up nights watching the cars. This was under the only street light in the area and across the street from out "courtesy" officer, a police officer with a K9 unit. Between October and January there were at least another dozen car break-ins. NO alert was given by management. I guess we were supposed to find out on our own. January 2011, I was doing my laundry early in the morning, the only time when washers and dryers were available thanks to people who leave their clothes in the laundry for hours and even days. I came out to my car, again parked under a street light, to find someone in the front seat cutting my radio out of the dash. I know I'm considered an idiot but I yelled at the man to get out of my car. I ended up being pushed down before I could hit the panic button. Fortunately, once the alarm went off, the man took off, as did the second man that I hadn't seen in the back of the car. They got my radio but left behind a pristine finger print and a screwdriver. I know I was very lucky that the screwdriver and the knife they used to get the radio weren't used on me. The next day there was a notice on the door of the laundry room basically saying it was the tenant's responsibility to take precautions against theft and attacks. I was picking up a package at the office and as I was walking out a young man was walking in wearing the same outfit as the second man from the night before. He saw me, then very quickly looked away to prevent me from clearly seeing his face. Two days later I saw the same young man with the man who had pushed me down at the bus stop. Again, they turned away quickly when they saw my car. I called the police but by the time they got here, the two men were long gone. When I mentioned the young man to the manager, I was told they knew exactly who I was talking about but they wouldn't give me any information because he was "a quiet tenant who always paid his rent on time". Later that week I saw this man walking through the parking lot with his dog. Again I'm not an expert but I know a pit bull when I see one. I informed management of this and was told he didn't have a dog and that pit bulls weren't allowed in the complex. When I pressed the issue I was promised that the "courtesy" officer would keep an eye on him. In June of last year my air conditioner stopped putting out cold air. Maintenance was called again and again the unit was not repaired. I can handle cold but the heat in this area is way to much for a Northerner like me. They came on Friday to replace the A/C unit. I came home to find a man I did not know in my apartment without the required 24 hour notice. He is lucky, as am I that my dog did not bite him. He discovered after disconnecting the old unit that the unit they had him installing was not the correct kind. So he went to see if he could get the right part and didn't come back. I found out from the office that this man was only here temporarily, that day was his last day and they would have to wait until Monday when the new maintenance man arrived to fix the unit. Fortunately the temperature wasn't that hot that particular weekend. I came home Monday to discover the unit was still not fixed. A call to the office resulted in my being told that the new maintenance man wouldn't come into the apartment because the dog was running loose. My dog was locked in the bedroom which is next to the entrance. The man thought he was loose because he was barking at the only window which is right by the door. They offered to have the guy come down right away. An hour later I called again to be told he was there, but that it looked like it was going to rain so he left. No knock, no call and still no air. The unit was finally fixed a week after it was reported. From January of last year until April of this year, the break-ins escalated from cars to apartments. I spoke with one officer who was parked in front of my building and was told there had been "another" break-in. When I questioned the "another" he told me there had been 8 break-ins in the previous three months. I was working with Durham police re my mugging and was told that the officer in charge was actively participating in an operation where undercover police officers were being put into the complex to see if they could stop the break-ins and, while they knew who was doing it, they couldn't get enough proof to put a stop to it. One woman who is physically handicapped actually had her door kicked in while she was there. Fortunately some people heard her screaming and chased the thief off. No alert was given by management. OH, they painted the buildings last year. Painted my back door shut so I can't get it open. Again, in all fairness, I don't use that door much and, if I had to get out, I definitely WOULD get out. At least I'm secure in the knowledge that door won't be broken in without my knowing it. They supposedly power washed all of the buildings before painting them. Interestingly enough, there are cocoons and hornets nests that are now a part of the building having been covered with paint. After the painting, the overhead light on the stairwell going to the second floor burned out every 4 to 6 weeks. That makes the front entry of all of the apartments in this building pitch black. It usually took at least three e-mails or calls to the office to get this situation taken care of. In the meantime, those of us leaving before dawn or getting home after dark, were forced to feel our way to the door or up the stairs unless someone left their front door light on. Late last month, I was finally called to do a photo lineup to see if I could identify my mugger, like I'd be able to do so after 14 months. I came close but chose the wrong guy. I was told then that, while the police knew who he was, the man was not in custody and they "hoped he had moved on". I was also told that the officer had just returned from the complex after investigating 3 break-ins that had occurred in broad daylight that very day. WHY, might anyone ask, have I stayed in this apartment with all of the crap that has been going down. Simply put, it's close to my work and the rent is reasonable. Also, every time my lease came up for renewal, we had a new management company that had just taken over or was taking over, and I hoped against hope they would actually make things better. And finally, the bad things seem to happen when I'm in the middle of a lease. I don't have the money to buy out the remaining months or to take them to court as my neighbor did (and she DID win) to get out early. I tell myself, at this point, a couple of months of peanut butter for breakfast, lunch and dinner, would have been worth it. Twice in the past 8 months, the management company has changed. The result was that we lost the best of the groups to date and have been inconvenienced because those of us who pay online were not informed until just days, hours in one case, before the rent is due. You can't just drop your rent in a box at the office if you pay by check, you have to give it to a human. For those of us who work odd hours this means going out of our way to get to the office during the hours of operation. After all that has happened in the past year, I've become afraid to walk out the door in the dark. Especially after finding out that the guy who mugged me is NOT in custody. One of my former neighbors has told me that she saw two men who resembled the two across the street from my apartment hiding behind the dumpsters. She may have been wrong, but how can I be sure? I had decided not to renew my lease this time but once again a new manager came in and I thought I would give her a chance. BUT, once again, things have happened and I was fortunate that I could change my mind before the lease was up. The rent was screwed up again and we found out when the old company sent an e-mail cancelling the payment. They COULD have taken the payment and made us fight to get it back but fortunately they were honorable this time. In addition to this I received a notice on my door on March 7th that my lease had expired the day before and that I needed to come to the office to discuss this matter. I called because my lease is supposed to run until June 30th, and was told it was a "word processor" error and they were just trying to let me know that the lease was coming to an end. I don't know about you, but if I was sending out a notice like that, I would CHECK it before it was delivered. I did however find out that my lease did NOT run to June 30th but was actually up on June 28th. Had I not called I would have not known of the difference and my vacate notice would not have been given in time to allow for a 60 day notice. On Monday of this week, I received a reminder that I needed to let the office know if I was going to renew my lease. Yesterday I sent my notice to vacate in June. I sent the notice certified mail, return receipt requested. Today received a phone call telling me that they had received my notice but that it wasn't valid unless I came into the office and signed an "Official" notice. NONE of this was mentioned in the reminder because they "don't expect people to want to leave". When I suggested they might THINK about putting that in the notice, I was told I didn't have to send the vacate notice certified, it says so in the lease that I didn't get. I went to the office, read and signed the paperwork, and was THEN given a one page, two column list of items that needed to be taken care of when I moved or I would be fined. These items were supposedly listed in my lease - oh, by the way, did I mention that I too did not get a copy of the lease? Regardless I KNOW nothing was in the lease saying that I had to have the carpet "professionally cleaned" and that I must provide them with a receipt for said cleaning or I will be fined even though I own and use my own steam cleaner. The tile (linoleum at best) floors are to be cleaned AND waxed. OH, but the good news is I can hire them to do it for me for only $105.00 When I tried to get the signed paperwork back, I was told I had already signed it so too bad, so sad. I asked about the fact that they were doing a "pre move-out" walk thru in the "next few days" and I hoped they still had the copies of the pictures I took of the tile peeling back from the wall and the blinds on the back door that were broken when I moved in in 2006. Of course, they don't so I'm sure they will be trying to fine me for that too. To say the least I had planned to clean the apartment before I left. I have lived in many apartments in my life and have never had so much as one complaint about the way I had left them. At this point I'm not going to waste my time. I'll pay the $105.00 and consider it money well spent to be rid of these people. ********************* UPDATE **************************** Today I FINALLY received a copy of my lease. In the document was a paragraph, helpfully highlighted by the agent, that reads "38. Cleaning. You must thoroughly clean the apartment, including the doors, windows, furniture, bathrooms, kitchen appliances, patios, balconies, carports and storage rooms. You mus follow move-out cleaning instructions IF THEY HAVE BEEN PROVIDED. If you don't clean adequately, you'll be liable for reasonable cleaning charges." They seem to think this allows them to provide random cleaning instructions at any time and change them as they see fit...they might want to think again! 1) The cleaning instructions were provided ONLY after I signed the notice to vacate. 2) There is NO mention in the lease of PROFESSIONAL cleaning of the carpets. My attorney has read the lease and has given me the following advice. There is no document in existence that has my signature acknowledging that I would have the apartment professionally cleaned nor was I notified AT THE TIME THE LEASE WAS SIGNED that it would be necessary for me to do so. The notice of professional cleaning is not with the "four corners of the contract" allowing this management to randomly make changes without my knowledge or my approval. This is not only highly unethical but could be just cause for legal action. They've already lost one lawsuit. I'm willing now to go for two. Adding I TRULY feel sorry for the person who moved into this apartment next. I'm sure that the best they can hope for is painting over the mold and if they are really lucky new carpet that will hide the stains on the under-layment for a few months at best. One more note: My copy of the lease, that I finally received, shows an end date of June 30th, 2012, not the 28th as I've been repeatedly told. Make sure you read the lease carefully and GET A COPY!! 2011 - 2012 Recommended Property Reviewed 03/02/2012
I have lived at several apartment complexes since 2008...starting at Magnolia Pointe and moving to Morreene West, but The Forest Apartments are by far the best place I have lived since I moved away from home. I live in a 2 bedroom 2 bath apartment with my fiance--our first place together :) and we have loved every minute of it! We have a balcony and a fireplace and a great deal with a washer & dryer company. The grounds are wonderful and even have access to the Duke Forest walking trails. There is a pool and a nice workout facility. They have furnished and unfurnished apartments and they do allow pets (there is a fee of course but NO pet rent like most places.) Anytime we have had ANY problems (maintenance, noisy neighbors, etc) the staff as been GREAT about taking care of the problem. Emily is always very helpful and responds in a timely matter to all of my emails and questions. We just love living here and we plan on renewing our lease for at least another year. Not only is it a great location, but it is a great price. Another thing that I really love about this complex is the fact that Duke recommends it to all of their transplant patients as the closest and safest location to Duke. If you are looking for somewhere to rent, definitely check this place out..you won't regret it!

Resident
2011 - 2012 Recommended Property Reviewed 02/12/2012
Abundance of mature trees complementing the outer decor of the scattered buildings lends a rural, community, woodsy feel to this apartment complex. Although close to Durham and Duke University, it feels to be on the outskirts. I like to be able to say that I live in the American Village of Durham, a quite attractive and desirable section. I value the pretty walks in the Duke Forest just steps from my door, and enjoy my open balcony. Although the unit is closest to the passing street, motor vehicle noise is usually tolerable. The railroad tracks which curve around no closer than a mile allow for the sound of a train now and then - which I find comforting. I like feeling to be living out in the woods, while still being close to attractions. Durham has much to offer - a kind of tasty place. One could walk to Duke University in about 25 minutes - if one wanted to walk; or a bus comes every hour. The university and central Durham are bicycle accessible from here. The buildings are somewhat old, but were probably originally designed to be rather luxurious. Am confident with the upkeep and maintenance. I like living out in the woods, while still being close.

At first, I loved this place. It was cheap, it was close to Duke with a bus that came every hour, and Emily was great. However, several changes have taken place lately and it's been chaos. First, I have not seen Emily in some time. Not sure if she's still with management, but if she's not, that would explain why things have gotten out of control. Here are several problems: -people keep stealing the stupid tredmil magnets so the machines won't work and it takes forever for the office to get them replaced -the buttons on the doorpad to the mail room have been stolen, also, so now the door is always unlocked, this happen months ago -keypad to the workout room also suffered problems and was also left unlocked for an unreasonable amount of time, also no ac in the room so with all the huge windows you work out in an oven -for a studio apartment, setting the thermostat to 73 in summer, a $70 electric bill is ridiculous -three ant infestations in two years (they are coming from a crack that must be under the carpet -allowance of large breed dogs in studio apartments on second floors- common, show some common sense -main building lights are frequently out, so if you plan to return after dark, you need to leave your own front light on -8 washers and 8 dryers for the entire comple to use.... Serious problem for the amount of washer/dryer-less units -hazardous parking lot with the way people drive on a supposedly 10mph road -I have a 'bath-fitter' tub and it is beyond disgusting. The top and bottom pieces were not joined together properly and when I step into the tub, the bottom piece pulls down, creating a crack around the tub that I have no hope of keeping clean. It's grosser than gross and the reason I think I got my rent so cheap. Wish I knew before what I was getting.... aquatic 03/28/2012

I AM the person that wrote the black mold review, I WON the court case (and I can prove it), and the mold was an existing condition upon move-in, NOT a result of lack of cleaning on my part. The bathroom ceiling was sagging and covered in mold spots, so there was clearly an internal problem with the building. I asked my next-door neighbor if she had seen signs of mold and she responded that yes, the previous summer her entire bathroom ceiling had collapsed on her and revealed insulation blackened with mold from leaking skylights on the second floor. Apparently when the complex went to fix the ceiling they initially refused to replace any of the insulation, claiming that the insulation was supposed to be black. The mold was determined to be stachybotrys (it IS neurotoxic) after an air-quality test performed by an independent and certified inspection agency that I was forced to hire, using my own money, after the complex refused to do any testing or take any measures on their own. I have never posted a negative review about another complex in my entire life and I do not work for a competing complex. I am a graduate student at Duke.

anonymous 02/12/2012

I'm not sure how this person was able to 'verify' their mold was of the neurotoxic species. Currently, as by the CDC, there is NO speciation test and they do not suggest performing one. If that person was growing mold, it was because they were not running their fan, opening windows, ect. I see mold pop up in my apartment (a NON-corporate, leased apartment) and I deal with it accordingly.... By cleaning. Overall, I have had a lovely experience living here while I attended grad school. The apartments are not expensive, they allow animals (although they may want to reconsider allowing large dogs in second floor studios), the grounds are well kept, people generally clean up after their dogs, the office staff is FANTASTIC and Emily is very professional, and it's only a few miles from Duke. Any minor complaint I've had has been dealt with rapidly and professionally. Unfortunaltely, it's up to individual tenants to make the apartment community a nice place to live and some people just aren't able to be conscientious about living so closely- it's not something the office staff can screen for. I will be recommending this place to the incoming students in my program.

The facility was very well manicured, clean, and there was an obvious sense of pride and camaraderie amongst the leasing / maintenance team (especially since I even ran into the maintenance team out in the parking lot as I was leaving). So, anyway, I did want to amend my earlier statement given that I unfortunately received some bad info from a 3rd party and would never want to unfairly malign someone else. Resident
2010 - 2011 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/12/2011
I have lived in various apartments all over Durham during my long haul as a student. My time at the Forest Apartments has been overall positive. They offer both normal apartments for rent, as well as furnished apartments that can be rented daily, weekly or monthly. I've lived in both types and will provide a quick review of both below. All-in-all, there are "better" and newer apartments available all over Durham, but I found that the Forest has the best combination of location, amenities and price. Location: minutes from the university, hospital & grocery store, on the bus line & right in Duke Forest for hiking & running. Quiet. Amenities: pool, exercise room, laundry on-site, tennis courts, office will hold your packages for you Staff: helpful but there can be issues as they keep changing. the ones I have dealt with have been professional and friendly. Maintenance usually came relatively quickly if there was a problem. Tenants are a mix of students, young professionals, ppl with small families and random others. Definitely a variety! Lots of folks with pets. Furnished apartments: 1 & 2 bedrooms available, with decent furniture, cable & electricity included in price. They provide linens, vacuum, mop, microwave, full kitchen (like being in a hotel). Most reasonably priced I found in the area. Some have in-room laundry machines. The cons: older buildings with less efficient (and less powerful) AC/heat, etc. Management company has changed many times and although the staff is helpful, they keep changing! Exercise room usually has one broken and one usable treadmill. You live in Duke Forest, meaning your power is more likely to go out during a storm. There were a few car break-ins during my time there. I don't think the area is unsafe at all, but in general, I think the area has gone a little downhill over the past 10 years.

It is very family friendly, very quiet. We have two kids (2 yrs old and 1 month old) so that is important to us. We particularly enjoyed the fact that some of the apartments are furnished and can be rented by the day. Our parents and friends visiting us from afar probably rented overall around 2-3 months in probably 6 different units. It was really convenient. We now have to leave out of country, but we will miss our live at the Forest. We felt very much at home.

2006 - 2010 Recommended Property Reviewed 07/02/2010
This is an outstanding place to live. It is safe (for Durham) and very well-maintained. I lived there for four years, while studying at Duke Med. I never experienced any problems with bugs, and maintenance issues were always handled promptly. The staff is efficient and the most recent manager has done an excellent job improving and managing the complex. Parking is always available. The tenants are mostly good neighbors, especially considering the low cost of rent and the fact that you are in Durham (not the nicest city to say the least). I would recommend this complex to anyone looking for a one-bedroom near Duke in the $600 range.

Resident
2008 - 2009 Not Recommended Reviewed 07/16/2009
I actually really enjoyed living at The Forest the first few months. True, within a week of me being there the electric box for my apartment went out and it was almost two weeks before it was repaired correctly. However, in October I started seeing these little bugs. I thought they were water bugs, and I saw only a few a month. Then in the end of November I saw a very large American roach crawling on my wall. I complained to the office and they told me I really should take care of it myself since I had a small dog. So I went out and bought Raid bug bombs and fumigated my place in December. When it was done, there were approximately 10 or so of those small bugs and two very large American roaches. I thought the problem was solved, but I continued to see these water bugs every few weeks or so. At the beginning of February, my downstairs neighbor apparently complained of roaches and so they sprayed his place and mine to prevent the roaches from coming up into my place when they left his. As February progressed, I began to see those water bugs more and more frequently, about one a week or so. It was annoying and finally I looked them up online only to figure out at the end of February that they were actually German cockroaches. I was killing several a week at this point, approximately 3 or 4 a week. I complained to management and they had pest control come and treat my apartment on the first week of March. They said it should be fine after that, but shortly after that I was up to killing one a day. They were everywhere, mostly in the kitchen and bathroom, but also saw several in the living room. Apartment was treated the first time after I complained on March 9th, then again on March 16th because I was still seeing them. Place was also treated on March 30th and April 13th, and in this time, over the course of a week I was averaging killing at least one a day, sometimes two. Between March 20th and April 15th, I killed 35 roaches (I kept a diary for documentation). April was hell. I was killing 3-4 roaches a day by the end of the month and pest control was coming every single week. Fortunately they began giving me a key to stash my dog in another apartment that was empty so she wouldn t be exposed directly to the chemicals. They use something that is supposed to kill the roaches after a week or so and make them sterile, but I saw very little evidence of effectiveness. Also, at the end of March they did an inspection of the building to see if they could pinpoint the problem, because I kept my apartment very clean. They found nothing. They did another inspection in the middle of April and again found nothing. Finally, at the beginning of May, they found that the apartment behind mine was filled with roaches. I was informed that I was actually lucky to ONLY be seeing four or five a day and that this person had 1000s of them in his apartment. They began treating his apartment and mine every week, but not the whole building (there are 16 apartments in that building). As far as I am aware, only one or two other people had seen a few roaches as of the time that I moved out. The roach situation never improved. They did give me half of my rent off for the months of May and June and let me out of the contract for the month of July, but I dealt with 100s of roaches over the 6 month course of the infestation. As far as I am aware, they did not evict the problem guy, but were intending to simply let his lease run out. As far as I know, he is still there in building 2400. They were very nice about it, but were also very ineffective at both locating the source of the problem, taking me seriously about it, and finally fixing it. To be fair a friend of mine still lives there and really likes it, but I would never live there ever again and would not recommend it even with the nice management.

2006 - 2008 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/21/2008
Over all I am satisfied with my living experience here at the Forest Apartments. The apartments are clean, safe, quiet and located in an ideal location for being a graduate student at Duke University. The staff is friendly but they are slow to respond and react to questions. I have never had them call me concerning a problem, even when they say they will call me that day. The heating and air units do not provide adequate climate control at a reasonable expense. To have a comfortable temperature inside we have to pay an expensive electric bill. Brandon Gilmore, unit 721.

Resident
2006 - 2008 Recommended Property Reviewed 04/30/2008
I have lived here for almost two years, and will be sad to leave. First, it is extremely close to school- I can walk to duke easily. There is a bus stop right outside my door which also takes me to school or downtown. The neighborhood is so safe, nobody ever comes up to my door, and I have our bikes parked (unlocked) on our front porch. THe neigbors are quiet and decent. THe only problem with this apartment complex might be the maintenance- they are off and on. FOr example, I complained about my dishwasher not working, they replaced it with a brand new one within a week. On the other hand, I have had a leak in the bathroom and the kitchen ever since I moved in, and they have never fixed it, claiming that they need to change the roof first. That is frustrating. However, I believe that the price is right for what you get, it is super quite and nice to live surrounded by trees. The apartment is also sunny, as long as you get a 2nd floor one, and is very comfortable. On the whole, I would definitely recommend it, and say that if you have a maintenance issue, complaining a lot normally gets the thing fixed.

Resident
2006 - 2007 Recommended Property Reviewed 06/30/2007
When I read the reviews, I felt compelled to add something much more positive to the current comments. Our family has lived here almost year now, and it is by far the best place we have ever lived. I find the price very resonable, despite the fact that there are other apartments a little bigger for a comparable price. This is because many kinds of deals are available, such as good student, Duke employee, ect, if you just ask. Also, utilities are set up in a very economical way, so it all evens out. Noise is not an issue. We were living in a house before and were worried that there might be more noise than we were used to. But most houses nowadays have very thin walls and/or construction. We were pleasantly surprised to find that in this older, sturdier building I can sleep better than I have in any of our other places. It is a friendly place. The office provides breakfast in the mornings and an occasional holiday party. Management, for the most part, has been very helpful. We came shortly after a turnover in management, and major problems have always been fixed the same day. It's true that if you have a chip off your lampost, management may not consider it important enough to fix. So if you grew up with a maid, were given your first car at sixteen, and daddy paid for your grad school, it may not be up to your standards. Some apartments do get moldy. However, we were warned about this upon move in and were told that how often we leave our windows/doors open is directly related to how moldy that apartment can get. We have never had a problem with mold. I feel very safe. I have no problem letting my six-year-old play outside with the other children. They are often involved in a neighborhood game of baseball, and they watch out for each other concerning issues like oncoming cars. Cars usually drive through slowly, and the office sends out reminders to the tenants during the spring that children will be running and playing outside more often. Also, a policeman lives just across the way. Lastly, it is beautiful. The woods are beautiful, the paths are beautiful, the gounds are kept beautifully, and families of deer may approach your door hoping for you to feed them apples. I highly recommend this not only as a nice apartment complex but as a wonderful neighborhood.

Everything in this apartment has been handled well, clean, well equipped, any MINOR problems we have experienced (very FEW) have been handled quickly and in a very professional manner. Management has been most helpful in seeing that all our needs have been met; people residing in other apartments are friendly; no problems with excessive barking by dogs, absolutely NO problems with children in the area....as a matter of fact, we're impressed that the parents are ALWAYS outside with their children while the children are playing (parents are actively involved, or sitting in the area reading as the children are playing.) A good mix of residents, (i.e. students, medical professionals, people here for medical treatment[as are we], working people and families). A good, secure place to live as far as we are concerned - we are BOTH professionals at retirement age!
