Resident
2006 Recommended Property Reviewed 09/29/2006
I have been at the Forest for nearly 4 months now. As with most places, there are positives and negatives:<br><br>Positives: 1) The price is cheap - I pay $550 and the place is ok. 2) Cleanliness - my place was very clean when I moved in, and the grounds are relatively well kept. 3) Safety - I do not fear break-ins, and it seems safe at night. Yet some of my neighbors are rather low-class and shifty. 4) Close to Duke - this may not affect you as much. 5) Close to the Duke Forest. 6) The swimming pool and little gym are ok, though more of a curio than functional (though the kids seem to enjoy the pool). <br><br>Negatives: Ok here it comes. 1) Management Incompetence - I would heartily agree with some recent postings that the staff is a mess. An example: my toilet has been running for over a month. The first time they 'fixed' it, the jerk working on it smash the inside mechanism, causing the tiolet to running at full tilt. He left trash in my apartment, grease on the walls - even throwing stuff on my bed! This occurred while I was away, so it ran this way for four days!! Since then, they have come and gone multiple times, and the repair guy never gets it right. The management seems ignorant and careless in their overseeing of it all. Another example: The seam to my front window is busted, and water vapor clouds the view. They assured me it would be repaired months ago, and despite repeated calls they never do it. I get the distinct sense that after you hang up the phone, they joke about your complaint. 2) Bad neighbors - many of my fellow tenants are messed up. One neighbor OD'ed late at night. Another has multiple thug boyfriends straight out of the hood. Ironically, the reason the Forest has some low clientelle is because of the low rent, so I guess you have to take the bad with the good. 3) The swimming pool area is often utilized most by the trashiest people at the apartment complex - fat, stupid, loud and young.<br><br>I have tried to be fair in my appraisal of the place. I certainly don't hate it, though I am not sure whether I will resign for next year. If money is not an issue, choose elsewhere. If it is, then the Forest is a serious consideration, though by no means the best choice. They have recently undergone a change in ownership, so hopefully that will improve things.

The apartments are okay and the rent is acceptable, but the management is awful. They are all very nice, but utterly incompetent. Expect needing to make multiple maintenance request to get any meaningful response. Expect to receive late payment notices even though you paid early. Keep receipts of all transactions ever made, and keep a copy of your lease in case they try to change the rules on you (e.g. kick you out with less than the required 60-day notice, charge you a higher late fee than the contract allows, etc.). I will never live at the Forest Apts again...if you want to, good luck and watch you back.

Resident
2003 - 2005 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/20/2005
I've lived here for two years in a studio apartment (about 450 sq ft). The appliances are old but works. The buildings are kinda old, but not too run down. My floor squeak a lot in certain places and the faucets drips a lot. I also have occasional problems with cockroaches and spiders. Aside from that, it's a pretty nice and quiet community. A lot of the first floor apartments are rented out on short term to people who come to Duke Med for treatment. Parking is pretty good, and I haven't experienced any crime. The laundry room gets crowded on weekends and costs $2.25 to wash and dry a load. The fitness room is small and but it's almost always occupied in the evening and I would have to wait awhile to use the equipment. Most people here are grad students and people who work at Duke. I never hear anything from my neighbors, only the sound of doors opening and closing. The office staff is okay, they usually handle my requests promptly. The maintenance sometimes need a couple reminders before they come around to fix the problem. Overall, I had a pretty good stay here since I didn't experience any horrible treatment or had any major issues.

Resident
2004 Recommended Property Reviewed 11/14/2004
The Forest is an older apartment complex. I signed a 6 month lease because I was in a time crunch and had to find a place close to Duke in a very short time. The maintenance staff has been decent -- things were usually fixed correctly, but not always in a timely manner. I am moving at the end of the year -- but they try to trap you into a "self-renewing" lease that will make you financially liable unless you turn in all the necessary deadline 2 months before you move out. <br><br>Unless you get a special rate, you really aren't getting what you pay for. Rent isn't expensive, but the kitchen is covered in hideous 70's style wallpaper and the appliances are neither reliable nor new. The lighting is horrible in the apartments -- mine includes 2 tiny windows and a cheesy plastic chandelier over the dining table. <br><br>Parking depends on which building you live in, but is usually never a problem. My car was broken into once -- the office staff bascially told me "yeah, it happens." <br><br>Overall, it's a decent place to live, but if you have the money or time, shop around for something better.

Resident
2003 - 2004 Recommended Property Reviewed 08/02/2004
I have lived in The Forest for a year now. I really have no major complaints. It is an older apartment complex, but they have been doing many upgrades. I could live in Deerfield across the street, which is newer, but I wasn't willing to pay 200 more a month for the same size apartment I'm in now. The maintenance staff have been extremely efficient and helpful. They even came over to get a HUGE spider off my front door. The office staff are nice, but are not overly friendly. They can give the impression they are overworked and annoyed you are bothering them, however they have always taken care of my needs, so I can't ask for more.<br>I've always felt safe and love the surroundings.<br>My only complaint is the walls are thin and I can hear my neighbors walking above me as if they are stomping, when in reality they are walking normally. For this reason, I would rent on the 2nd floor.<br>Overall, for safety and an economically priced apartment, I would highly recommend.

Resident
2002 - 2004 Not Recommended Reviewed 01/29/2004
We have lived here for two years in a 1-bdr on the second floor. The first year that we were here we didn´t have any major complaints except that we were paying $100/month more than our neighbour who had the exact same apartment. They agreed to lower our rent to a fairly good price so we stayed. There is still a fair amount of mold growing in the bathroom from various water leaks, and the roof is starting to fall apart since the hurricane storm of Sept 2003. Maintenance doesn´t seem to care. As for noise, that really depends on your neighbours, we only have one loud one but other than that it is extremely quiet. <br> <br>The office staff are not trust worthy and we have caught them in more than one lie. One girl even admitted that we were mislead. The laundry machines are often broken and a third of the time the clothes come out dirty after washing. Most of the machines also have mold growing in them but since the Forest doesn´t operate them there is nothing they can do about them. <br> <br>The location is nice though and that is why we chose to move there. One other review mentioned that there was good bus coverage to Duke, but that is not entirely true. The bus comes once an hour and if it is running late it will skip over this stop since it is the last stop. On average the 9:00am bus is missed once a week. <br> <br>Overall, this isn´t the worst place but you have to realize that the office staff will say anything to get you to sign the lease, property rules change all of the time, but it is quiet and is very close to Duke Forest.

Resident
2001 - 2002 Recommended Property Reviewed 05/22/2003
I lived at The Forest for a year while I was an undergraduate at Duke. I rented a 2 bedroom/2 bathroom apartment with a roommate. The actual apartment was quite nice. We had a large living area, along with two nice-sized bedrooms. One drawback was the lack of light in the living room and one of the bedrooms, as we were facing the woods. Also, some genius decided to put dark mini-blinds in the dark rooms and white mini-blinds in the one room that had a lot of sunlight. <br> <br>In terms of life at The Forest, I was not impressed. I lived on the second floor, on top of a furnished apartment that was rented out to cancer patients at Duke hospital for the entire time that we lived there. Because we lived on top of people who were sick, we constantly had to tiptoe around in order to avoid getting noise complaints being made against us. I´m not talking wild parties or anything; we would be reported just for walking around the apartment at night. This is not an ideal situation for either the hospital patients trying to sleep or the college students who need to be up late. If you´re going to live here, you might request to live on the first floor or at least not above a furnished apartment. <br> <br>Maintenance was not a strong suit either. Our heat and air conditioning were broken for most of our stay at The Forest. Despite the fact that we reported it multiple times, it took months of complaining and finally threatening to call a repair service ourselves to get it fixed. Also, I did battle with maintenance for several months because squirrels were nesting in the roof above my bedroom. This problem was never fully rectified. <br> <br>On the plus side, the office staff is very nice and helpful, and they are good about fixing emergencies like clogged toilets, etc. They have a maintenance person on call 24 hours a day if you have an emergency, including being locked out. I even had a maintenance person fix an emergency on Thanksgiving within 20 minutes of my call. The gym is also very nice, and only a few years old. <br> <br>Overall, The Forest is not a terrible place to live. I definitely enjoyed being right on the edge of the Duke Forest, and away from the commotion of being right near campus. Also, I felt pretty safe, which is saying a lot for an apartment complex in Durham.

Leasing

If being close to everything is an important item on your neighborhood checklist consider it crossed off when you choose to live at The Forest Apartment Homes. We're conveniently located near downtown Durham, Duke University, and Duke Medical Center. The 9th Street District, The Streets at Southpoint Mall, and Brightleaf Square are all just a short drive away as well, which means all of the best shopping, restaurants, and entertainment Durham has to offer is in your backyard.Allow us to captivate and spoil you in the relaxing, maintenance-free apartment homes at The Forest. Bask in a home filled with comforts and conveniences and an assortment of amenities that make it hard to ever leave. Choose from well-appointed studio, one, and two bedroom floor plans and relax in the secluded retreat - enveloped in natural beauty - in your new home at The Forest in Durham, North Carolina.
